Once shares are outstanding, unless the company buys them back, they remain outstanding no matter who owns them. If the company issues 50 million shares in an IPO via the underwriter, then they have 50 million shares floating. When shares change hands, it‚Äôs not new shares and not dilutive.

Wall Street expectation correlates strongly with overall economic growth. When the economy is doing well, there's actually more pressure on the CEOs to deliver revenue and profit growth that at least match the overall economy.

I have heard executives first hand who said it's much easier to run companies with low Wall Street expectation, i.e. companies themselves don't grow much, but get higher net profit through lower tax bills. And for them individually, they love lower tax bills even more.

However, for now, it seems that the market is taking Fidelity's entry into the Solana ETF race with caution.

The approval of a SOL ETF could still have implications for Solana's adoption and mainstream recognition. If approved, it could make it easier for institutional investors to gain exposure to Solana (SOL), potentially driving up demand and prices.
The token's price has been relatively stable since the announcement, indicating that investors are not expecting significant gains from Fidelity's entry into the Solana ETF race.

The news comes as Polymarket bettors currently see an 85% chance of a SOL ETF being approved this year. Other investment behemoths, such as Franklin Templeton, have also filed to launch a Solana ETF in late February.

Fidelity's entry into the Solana ETF race is significant, given its status as a mutual fund giant with $4.9 billion in assets under management. However, the market has already priced in this development, and Solana (SOL) added only a minuscule 1% in response to the announcement.

A statutory trust registration filing was submitted in Delaware last week, and it was clear that this would be followed by an actual ETF filing. This move mirrors Fidelity's existing cryptocurrency products.
Solana (SOL) has failed to rally on the news of Fidelity's official entry into the Solana ETF race. The filing, which was expected, did not come as a surprise to market participants.
